title: Fatigue Effects
content: Fatigue degrades cognitive performance as severely as alcohol intoxication—being awake 17 hours equals 0.05% blood alcohol; 24 hours equals 0.10% (legally drunk). Fatigue impairs judgment, reaction time, attention, and memory—and critically, it impairs your ability to recognize you're impaired. Self-assessment of fatigue is notoriously unreliable.

mcq.question: A team member has been awake for 20 hours during an extended operation. When asked, they say they feel fine and can continue safely. How should this self-assessment be weighted?

options.A: Trust their judgment—they know their own state best
options.B: Give it moderate weight—fatigue affects people differently
options.C: Give it low weight—fatigue impairs the ability to assess one's own impairment
options.D: Rely only on visible signs of fatigue like yawning

mcq.explanation: A key effect of fatigue is impaired self-assessment. People reliably underestimate their own impairment when fatigued. Objective indicators (hours awake, quality of recent sleep) are more reliable than subjective self-reports.

openQuestions: What objective indicators does your organization use to manage fatigue risk, beyond self-reporting?
Describe a time when you were more fatigued than you initially realized. What eventually made you recognize it?
